text: Bottle from Lisais CHester Market. Copper with slight chill haze lasting head and lace. Grassy honey toasted caramel aroma. Medium toasted almonds caramel honey vanilla sweetness with medium earthy spicy peppery bitterness in crisp finish. Light body lively fine carbo. It would be pretty hard to make one of these better than this. Excellent.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2017 Can at Nosh.  Better than any macrobrew lager, but pretty mediocre otherwise. Inoffensive, good with food. A bit watery.

Keg at The Farmhouse, Burlington.  Hazy amber, mid sized head. Gentle bready malt aroma. Mid dry with medium body and well rounded mouthfeel. Toasty firm malt, mild grassy hops. Mid bitter finish. Harmonious and very likable.
A watery malt aroma pours a clear orange color without much of a head. A sweet malt taste with a watery body and a sugary finish.
On tap at Whole Foods, Columbus Circle. Nice gold body with big head. Nose is malty, cereal. Taste is malts, cereal, bitter. Crispy, dry finish.
Pours amber with a white head. Grainy malt aroma and yeast. Flavor is grain, caramel, and bready malt up front with some fruit flavors. Spicy yeast finish.

Draft. Deep golden brew with tan head. Aroma of light malt and simple astringent hops. Taste is mild malt sweet with a simple and restrained hops finish, astringent with some light grass and crisp fruit. Very good.
Draft sample at the source. Clear copper with a white head of foam. Aroma is spice and wood. Munich character. More sweet. Medium body and medium carbonation.

Tap to start the Troy beer fest my main goal in attending is try new NY breweries and up New England ticks when possible. Amber pour. Thinnish nose of cereal and malt. Tastes of cereal, burnt hay, some earth. Thin bodied but drinkable and pleasant on this lovely afternoon.

On tap at von Trapp taproom. Pours out a rich crisp golden topped with a small head. Nose is light roast malts honey sweetness and a little wood. Taste is more of the light roast malts and the sweetness.
On tap at brewpub. Caramel aroma. Nutty, toasty taste, though a little watery. Overall fine but watery.

Bottle at Sander stag. Pours clear gold with a frothy, white head. Biscuit and cereal in the nose, some toasted hay, very slight caramel. Light sweet flavour with more biscuity character, faint leafy bitterness, more cereal, hay. Light bodied with fizzy carbonation. Fairly crisp on the finish, with dry pale bread, dried cereal grains, light bitter straw. Nice lager.

Cloudy orange-dark-golden with off-white top that fades quickly to a ring. Aromas of bread along with some spice and flora notes. Flavor is more subdued, mostly malty and toasty. Very slightly sweet finish. Decent stuff.

12 oz. bottle from Prost. Aroma is toasted grain, sulfur, and mild yeast. Flavor is a reflection of the aroma with some light hints of dark bread and maybe a toasted nutty hint. Body is pretty thin/ rides the line of watery. Overall nothing close to high end of the style but drinkable enough.
Not a big fan of the style but here it goes. Tastes like any other Vienna, sweet. Watery. Smell of burnt grape nuts. Ill pass on this one.

Pours a hazy burnt gold with a white head that quickly dissipates. Nose is slight malt. Body is medium. Taste is Munich malt with some complexity. Aftertaste has a higher hop bitterness lacking in other Viennas. Lighter in color than other Vienna lagers (Sam, Brooklyn, Leinenkugel, Dos Equis) but not in taste and bitterness. Very nice drink. 12 oz bottle in variety pack

Tap. Pours an orange/amber with not much head. Excellent Munich malt flavors are prominent. Mild hops and bitterness. The only fault I could find with this beer was a bit of an odd aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Pours hazy amber into a shaker. White head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Sour caramel and candy corn aromas. Medium bodied with dark malt and mild butterscotch front to back. Medium length earthy bitter finish.

Mild grain malt aroma. A clear golden amber body. Bold malt taste with only a hint of bitterness. Mild earthy sweet spice finish. Has a European lager quality(as best I can describe it) that I rarely taste in American craft brews.
12oz bottle-Thanks to Jeff Puboflyons for the trade. offwhite-gold. A-bready-grain with some sweetness. T-bready/cardboard-lt malt, some earthy/grassy hops.

4oz pour at Johnsons. Pours yellow gold with a persistent white head. Aroma is honey and cracker. Flavor is slow ghtly sweet, with honey, wheat, a touch of lemon and just a hint of saaz hop flavor in the finish. An easy drinking summer lager with no discernible flaws.

If Amber was gold, then this beer might get higher ratings, i.e. color is way off & obviously clashes w/ name of style.... Tastes reminiscent of Yuengling, which is a more true representation. Vermont H2O plays a big role here, Shed beers used to be made in Stowe but are produced in Middlebury VT now

This was poured into a pilsener glass. 
The appearance was a nice looking hazy golden orange color with a two finger white foamy head that dissipated within about thirty seconds leaving messy clingy lacing sticking to the glass.
The smell started off with crisp sweet nutty malts leading into a slight sweet biscuity edge.
The taste was mainly sweet through the combination of the nutty malts and biscuity aspect and also allowing a slight roastiness coming into balance. Theres a nutty aftertaste and a quick sweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. Carbonation feels right and leads to a nice smoothness about it.
Overall, this was a pretty good Vienna Lager that I could have again.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle. Olive-yellow pour with a long lasting white foamy head. The aroma is a little toasty, sulfur, slightly sweet, and thin grassy hops. Light to medium body. The taste has a touch more bitterness than the aroma lets on.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2015 From 12oz bottle, around $8 for 6pack

Aroma: very malty, low floral and spicy hops, slightly sulfur and yeasty

Appearance: crystal clarity, tan white head, Appeared Pale Yellow/Straw when tasting at BJCP group meeting and poured into sampling glass. However, it appears Amber when I opened another bottle and poured into pint glass.

Flavor: Good hop bitterness, clean crisp malt, somewhat nutty finish, grainy malts

Palate: medium body, moderate carbonation, creamy

Overall: A soft, smooth and creamy lager. with a clean taste and malty finish. Good, but nothing impressive. Not complex enough.
This is rather the typical sweetish American craft brewed lager-- amber-beige and malty. Nothing too complex and nothing offensive, but I prefer a little bit more from a good session beer.
Tap. Pours hazy orange, medium creamy white head, nice lacing. Flavor and aroma is malty, metal, caramel, dark breads, a bit nutty. Medium sweet, light plus bitter. Medium plus body, creamy mouthfeel
Tap. Hazy Amber pour with minimal head. Floral, soap, cereal, minerals. Chewy. Medium body. Like an unfiltered beer. Nice

On tap at Granite State on tap.
Lightly hazy deep golden color with a minimal head. Earthy bready pilsner with hints of fruit an floral spicy hops. Nice brew that I returned to a couple of times, but to be world glass it needs to clean up some rough edges.

Pours a clear amber with a thin white rim that leaves some lacing. Nose is of cereals and grain husks or at least nuts. Taste is of multigrain bread and sweet-ish. Body is medium and carbonation as well. Good!

Draft to taster. Looks solid; a slightly hazy orange with off-white head. Smells of amber malt and lager yeast with a bit of grain as well. Tastes like it smells with a pleasant medium-bodied mouthfeel. A decent example of the style.

En fut à la brasserie.
Dorée tirant sur le orangé, petite mousse qui colle très bien et qui laisse une belle dentelle.. En olfactif, on sent la levure lager avec de petits accents maltés. Au goût, on est dans lécorce de grain. Elle est sèche en bouche avec un petit arrière gout de houblon européen. Sa palette se situe surtout dans les grains de céréales. Une bonne lager.
Le miel oxydé suinte de partout, ca semble être une concotion trop verte. Finale mouillée, peu de rafinement.

[5283-20130428] Tap. Grainy light grape malt aroma. Clear, orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Light grainy fruit malt flavour. Medium body has a little bitterness. Average. (6/3/6/3/12) 3.0
(@ The Farmhouse, Burlington, VT)

Draft at the tap room at mt snow Vermont. Pours a lager looking flat color. No head . Decent .

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap (flight sampler) at Trapp Family Lodge: Pours slight hazy golden yellow with a thin white head. Malty aroma, with a bit of honey. Flavor is more of the same. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this and how well balanced it was. Light carbonation and a smooth finish make this very drinkable. Definitely worth a try.

A- pours a hazy light orange amber with a small off white head that lacks tenacity and weak lacing. S- good cereal grains and caramel malts. Some toffee. Honey and floral notes support. Hop notes of citrus, resin and grass are present as well. M- mild to medium body with decent carbonation. Sticky sweet palette. T- not much to elaborate upon here. Similar to smell. Starts with cereal grains and caramel malts. Good floral notes. bread and honey follow with a faintly bitter hop end of straw and citrus. Some malts on the end too. Very drinkable, but that about sums it up.
On tap @ the brewery. Pours a hazy golden amber with a thin white head. Aroma of caramel/toffee, with some light citrus hop notes. Taste is caramel, light roasted malts, and citrus.

Tap: Poured a light clear amber color lager with a small foamy head with good retention and some light lacing. Aroma of light cereal notes with light caramelized malt notes. Taste is a mix of light medium-sweet caramel malt with some cereal and grainy notes. Body is light with good carbonation. Nothing earth shattering here but well balanced and easily drinkable.

on tap at brewpub 
Aroma: medium intense. Quiet malty , sweeter walls. Neat presentation. 7+
Look: mild haze on amber with lighter white top. Some lace shown.3+
Flavour/body: Medium bodied. Nice malt feel , soft approach. Delicate. Reminded me a bit of Alt beers.

Pours deeper gold with a medium white head.  Aroma is toast and caramel.  Taste is sweet with very light bitters that add a touch of crispness.  Soft carbonation and a smooth mouth feel make this to easy to drink.  Enjoyed.
Draft at source. Rich amber color with a thin head of foam. Grainy, sweet malt with touches of honey and stale grass. Round caramel notes and a refreshing bitterness to clean up the finish. Not bad.

On tap at Trapp with Andy, Max, and Pearl.  Pours a clear amber with a thin white head.  Malty and crisp grain on the nose under a bit of caramel.  Grainy, light and crisp, grainy with a gentle bitterness.  Toast and grain with a bit of caramel and toffee.  Very tasty.

2013-04-28. Crisp golden body has a large creamy white Head.3++ Aroma is moderate, creamy grainy pale malt. Flavour has a creamy diacetyl like quality to it, mild toasty malt and bitterness. The Helles had a similar character, yeast? Smooth average bodied palate. Dont love it. On tap at Farmhouse, Burlington.

On tap in the lounge at the Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe, VT.

Hazy, amber golden-copper with small off-white head and good lacing.

Aroma of caramel, grain, toffee, grass and light hops.

Taste of toasted grain, light fruit, caramel and modest floral hops.

Medium body and medium carbonation.

A very tasty lager.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

En fût. Pinte dégustée chez Parker Pie Co. (West Glover, VT). Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est dorée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de caramel et de céréales. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #4422)

More clear golden than amber, small white head.  Aroma clean malt and bit of hay.  Medium-light body, small amount of carbonation.  Flavor does not seem like much at first but develops some yeasty malt and crisp grassy hop finish.  Just off-dry.  Nothing particularly memorable but well done, drinkable with food, just right for a session beer.

On tap at Mulligans in Manchester. Pours amber with a small head. Aroma is sweet and clean. Flavor is sweet and crisp, with a tangy thin finish, good enough.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the brewpub in Stowe, VT. Pours a crystal clear golden colored body with a finger-width, dense and frothy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a solid lacing throughout. Aroma is on the lighter side, but there is a very soft maltiness with a touch of sweetness. Bready, a hint of caramel, a touch of lager yeast, and a very light hopping. Flavor is similar. Very soft, bready malts with just a touch of caramel sweetness up front. A light lager yeast note with a touch of fruit in the middle and a bit of grain. A balancing, light herbal grassy bitterness comes on in the finish as this dries nicely before leaving a medium length aftertaste. Very soft, gentle, medium body with a very soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, not a bad Vienna. The flavor isnt anything special, but it drinks really nicely. Very soft with a great clean, dry finish.

Trapp Lodge: Pours a golden color with a white head (looks kind of similar to a German style Marzen as opposed to an American one). Aroma is light caramel malts. Taste is much the same. This is an easy downer and could easily be consumed in great quantities. Light hops are there as well, but considering them is almost an after thought. This is a proper session beer. Crisp and refreshing.
On draft at the brewery.  A nice orangish straw color. A little darker than the helles.  Crisp and refreshing.

I was amazed to find this on tap at a local watering hole, Kilkennys, in Milford NH. Pours a clear straw color with a barely there thin white cap, which disappeared immediately. Aroma was biscuit and cracker with a hint of floral hop. Flavor is white bread with butter & honey. Palate was surprisingly rich & full. Quite drinkable.

Expected a much darker color, but it pours a straw yellow color with a white head.  Aroma of caramel, hops, and toasted malts.  Good flavor and well-balanced with caramel and toasted malt as well as a good hop ending.  Good beer.

Glass on tap at Benelux.

Appearance : Slightly hazy pale yellow.

Aroma : Awesome malt with light caramel and herbal hops.

Taste : Great malt with caramel. Nice light fruits on finish. Lots of malt.

Overall : Soft carbonation, really nice malt and light herbal hops. I like this.
this is a very good session beer, not very distinctive but absolutely nothing not to like about it.  very good, soft flavor & aroma.  good to have more than one of .

Drank on tap (12 oz) at Benelux Brasserie Artisanale in Montreal, on June 11, 2011.Misty blonde, thin head. Aroma of dry  barley, hop herbs. Barley taste slightly sweet, well hopped, nice little bitterness. very nice, good drinking!

My Bottom Line:
This Viennas dull bready malts and faint herbal, spicy hops evolve in a highly drinkable mouthfeel. Good, but it would undoubtedly be better fresh at the brewery.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam covers the hazy light amber.
-A light yeasty touch mars the delicate malt profile.
-Even though I could pound this while never complaining, I would say there is still work to be done to make this as memorable as 7 Sterns,  Kadlez Bräus or Wieden Bräus session lagers, to name only those Viennese breweries.
-This brew was not as engaging as their Dunkles Lager had the same evening. Lots of drinkability, but the hops felt tired and the malt flavors werent as compelling.

On tap at Benelux.

On tap at brewery. Pours clear amber with a tight white head. Aroma was toasty with grains, faint caramel and bread. Flavor was malty and toasty with light caramel, grains, bread, and a touch of honey with a smooth clean finish.

On tap at the brewery.  Pours a clear orange with a small white head.  Aroma of caramel malt.  Flavor of sweet caramel malt and crackery malt, similar to the helles but sweeter.  The best of the bunch offered at Trapp Family Lodge (out of the helles, baltic porter, and dunkel) but thats not saying much...
6/4/6/3/13 [3.2/5]

In short: A basic and inoffensive Vienna.  Too clean but also very drinkable.
How: Tap at the brewpub
The look: Clear golden-blonde body topped by a very small white head
In long: Timid nose has light fruity esters.  Taste is a mix of dried fruits and fresh fruits (citrus fruits, bananas, pears).  Only a tiny little bit of caramel.  Discreet leafy hops.  Lively body.  Intensity level is very low.  This is the type of all-too-clean and polished lager I would expect from a mass produced can coming from a large scale respectable European lager brewery.  Inoffensively easy to drink.  One could say this is a conservative lager.  But I personally dont think it is made out of homophobes and guns.

Sampled at the brewery - Poures a light yellow in color with a medium bright white head.  Aroma is mostly malt with some faint hoppiness.  Flavor was light, but malty.  Nice example of this comparatively "rare" beer.

A golden vienna with a thin white head. In aroma, light chalky malt with smooth German hops. In mouth, a decent malty beer, with light herbal hops, medium bodied. nothing special. On tap at American Flat Bread, July 12 2010
